value: <l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">1</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">ANON.</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">"For many centuries <choice>
            <sic>afte</sic>
            <corr>after</corr></choice> Britain became an island"</quote> the</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-whar" key="Harrison, William">historian</rs> says "#"<quote source="#">the untamed forest was king. Its moist</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">and mossy floor was hidden from Heavens eye by a close drawn</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0"><quote source="#" rend="inline">curtain woven of innumerable tree tops."</quote> On those matted</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">boughs innumerable birds sang; but their song was only heard</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">by a few skin clad hunters in the <choice>
            <sic>lcearings</sic>
            <corr>clearings</corr>
          </choice>. Did the desire</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">to sing come to one of those huntsmen because he heard the</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">birds sing, and so rested his axe against the tree for a</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">moment? But the tree had to be felled; and a hut made</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">from its branches before the human voice sang too.</l>

<quote xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0" source="#" rend="block">
            <l>By a bank as I lay</l>
            <l>Musing myself alone, hey ho!</l>
            <l>A birdes voice</l>
            <l>Did me rejoice,</l>
            <l>Singing before the day</l>
            <l>And me thought in her lay</l>
            <l>She said, winter was past, hey ho!</l>
          </quote>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">The voice that broke the <choice>
            <sic>sielnce</sic>
            <corr>silence</corr>
          </choice> of the forests was</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">the voice of <rs type="person" ref="../resources/annotations.xml#psn-anon" key="Anon">Anon</rs>. Some one heard the song and <choice>
           <sic>re embered</sic>
           <corr>remembered</corr>
          </choice> it</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">for it was later <choice>
            <sic>wrteen</sic>
            <corr>written</corr>
          </choice> down, beautifully on parchment.</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">Thus the singer had his audience, but the audience was so</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">little interested in his name that he never thought to give</l>

<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">it. <del hand="ms">For</del> <add hand="ms" place="inline">T</add><del hand="ms">t</del>he audience was itself the singer; <quote source="#" rend="inline">Terly terlow"</quote></l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">they sand; and <quote source="#" rend="inline">"By, by lullay"</quote> filling in the pauses,</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">helping <add hand="ms" place="above">out</add> with a chorus. Every body shared in the emotion</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">of Anons song, and supplied the story. Anon sang because</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">spring has come; or winter is gone; because he loves; because</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">he is hungry, or lustful; or merry. or because he adores</l>
<l xmlns="http://www.tei-c.org/ns/1.0">some God. Anon is sometimes man; sometimes woman. He is the</l>
